trial_identification.studytitle: An open trial of examining the efficacy and acceptability of an internet-delivered cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) program for chronic pain augmented with daily SMS prompts.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: An open trial of examining the efficacy and acceptability of an internet-delivered cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) program for chronic pain augmented with daily SMS prompts.

interventions.interventions: All participants will complete 5 lessons of an Internet-delivered cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) treatment focusing on the management of pain, anxiety, depression and disability. One lesson will be completed every 7 to 10 days. Each lesson will take about 15 minutes to complete. Participants will also have access to summaries of each lesson, and will read anonymous stories about other people with chronic pain, taking a further 20 minutes per summary. All participants will also receive automatic email and weekly reminder phone calls by a clinical psychologist. The duration of the reminder emails and phone calls is expected to be 5-10 minutes per week. The duration of the program is 8 weeks. Study questionnaires will be administered at application, pre-education, post-education, and at 3-months post-education. These will take about 10-20 minutes to complete. Participants will be invited to receive generic SMS prompts and consenting participants will start receiving these prompts from week 3 of the course. The SMS prompts will be brief, limited to 1 a day on week days, and designed to remind participants to practice the skills during the day.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ), which measures disability associated with pain.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Administered at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and at 3-months post-treatment

primaryOutcome.outcome: Patient Health Questionnaire 9-Item (PHQ9), which is a measure of depression.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Administered at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and at 3-months post-treatment

primaryOutcome.outcome: Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item (GAD7), which is a measure of anxiety.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Administered at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and at 3-months post-treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Wisconsin Brief Pain Questionnaire (WBPQ), which is a general measure of the nature of participants pain including location, severity and duration.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Administered at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and at 3-months post-treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia (TAMPA), which measures fear of movement because of pain.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Administered at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and at 3-months post-treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The Pain Responses Self Statements (PRSS), which is a measure of catastrophic pain-related cognitions.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Administered at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and at 3-months post-treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Pain Self-Efficacy Questionnaire (PSEQ), which is a measure of peoples' beliefs about their ability to do daily activities despite pain.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Administered at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and at 3-months post-treatment

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - Has experienced Chronic Pain (i.e. Pain > 3 months) - Internet access + Printer access - Australian resident - Has had their pain assessed by their GP
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: - Psychotic disorder - Pain not assessed by GP - Current or planned psychological treatment during study duration

trial_design.concealment: Participants apply online, followed by a telephone interview to confirm presence of chronic pain and administration structured diagnostic interview using the Mini Neuropsychiatric Interview Schedule (MINI 5.0.0).

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This project is part of a research program to develop and evaluate an Internet-based education and treatment program for people with chronic pain. This project examines the efficacy and acceptability of a treatment program to enhance management of pain, anxiety, depression and disability amongst people with chronic pain, when augmented with daily SMS prompts reminder participants to practice self-management skills. We expect that participants will experience improvements across the measures and will rate the SMS prompts as acceptable and helpful.
